definitions.definition: To set (something, often a building) on fire.
To heat as with fire, but without setting on fire, as ceramic, metal objects, etc.
definitions.example: If you fire the pottery at too high a temperature, it may crack.

definitions.definition: To drive away by setting a fire.
To terminate the employment contract of (an employee), especially for cause (such as misconduct or poor performance).
To shoot (a gun or analogous device).
definitions.example: He fired his radar gun at passing cars.

definitions.definition: To shoot a gun, cannon, or similar weapon.
definitions.example: Don't fire until you see the whites of their eyes.

definitions.definition: To shoot; to attempt to score a goal.
To cause an action potential in a cell.
definitions.example: When a neuron fires, it transmits information.

definitions.definition: To forcibly direct (something).
definitions.example: He answered the questions the reporters fired at him.

definitions.definition: (computer sciences, software engineering) To initiate an event (by means of an event handler).
definitions.example: The event handler should only fire after all web page content has finished loading.

definitions.definition: To inflame; to irritate, as the passions.
definitions.example: to fire the soul with anger, pride, or revenge

definitions.definition: To animate; to give life or spirit to.
definitions.example: to fire the genius of a young man

definitions.definition: To feed or serve the fire of.
To light up as if by fire; to illuminate.
To cauterize.
To catch fire; to be kindled.
To be irritated or inflamed with passion.
The process of applying heat or fire, especially to clay etc to produce pottery.
definitions.example: After the pots have been glazed, they go back into the kiln for a second firing.

definitions.definition: The fuel for a fire.
The act of adding fuel to a fire.
The discharge of a gun or other weapon.
The dismissal of someone from a job.
Cauterization.
